title: New champs in ranked is a problem.
body: You guys remember when they changed it so that free champs couldn't be played in ranked? Well that needs to happen to newly released champs. Was in a ranked queue and a guys says not to ban Rek'Sai. Told him she was weak and he should play someone else. He picks her anyway and proceeds to go 0/12. Please at least make it so that new champs can't be played in ranked for a week. This is getting kind of stupid.

replies.body: I feel at least for the 1st week when they are 7800 they should be disable from ranked. My 2 cents.
This is what Smite does, and it's an AMAZING idea.
i haven't seen anything but Rek'Sai carrying since the hour of release

Do you mean Rek'Sai is carrying the team or the team is carrying Rek'Sai? Because I've seen nothing but the latter.

It depends on the person and the champion. I started playing Braum in draft games immediately after he was released to mostly positive success, but this came after I practiced with him in a custom game to understand his mechanics. Braum was also one of those champions who experienced a high ban rate almost immediately after his release.

I think the problem here is Rek'Sai fits in a relatively important role (jungler), and people who haven't practiced with him before are trying to learn him on the fly while trying to fulfill that important role end up doing neither. There's probably also a mentality players are going in with that causes them to take bigger, dumber risks because Rek'Sai can throw tunnels everywhere and therefore can maneuver past walls easily. I've seen too many first time Rek'Saiers trying to counterjungle only to get blitzkrieged by half the enemy team.

Rek'Sai is actually pretty easy to learn only after 3 matches with her i got used to it and started playing her right. but than again i own all the champions.

any champ can carry it depends on the experience of the player. complaining about new champs in ranked is silly if you don't even give a person the chance to prove themselves. sure if it's within the first hour ( like literal 30 minutes after release )  of course your gonna say no to that. but 6-8 hours after release that's enough time for someone skilled enough to learn a new champ and destroy with them.

and i doubt with all my heart anyone actually first times new champs in ranked for real. they will do a few normals but going straight to ranked is so rare of a thing for people to do.

also comparing every person online that plays first day champs to that one person in a game with millions of players is like singling out all those millions because of likely 1 dumb ass.
I'm just stating what I've experienced.
I have seen the former twice. But i guess it purely depends on the person. Did the person actually try her in normals before going ranked? That's probably the most important part.

They should make you have to win 2 normals with a champ before you can play them in ranked.

A possible problem with this would be owning champs for the purpose of first picking - you wouldn't be able to do that even if you were planning on trading them.

inb4 the obligatory "just ban them".

Although I completely agree, you shouldn't have to waste a ban just to ensure that your team isn't going to play the newest champion that no one knows how to play...

It'll never happen. Pro players should be able test new champions in solo queue as soon as they're released.

Also streamers would miss out on some of the new champion hype.

Rek'sai, weak? What are you smoking?
In my opinion, it's pretty fair to be using a champion once it is released. Given that I, among many others, have PBE access, I can easily test the champion and play it enough times until I feel confident to use it in ranked.

Honestly through, the real issue is players bringing any champions into ranked that they have not spent adequate time playin in normals. I woukd be ok with a system that forces a minimum of X games in normals before bringing any champions into ranked.  That way can always be sure players have some baseline of experience using whoever they lock-in.
Its more based on your ELO, in high elo if a player hasn't learned a champion they won't play it.
